title: Dow Jones Top Markets Headlines at 9 PM ET: Stocks Kick Off September on a Down Note Amid Rise in Bond Yields
content:
Stocks Kick Off September on a Down Note Amid Rise in Bond Yields

U.S. stocks fell after renewed inflation and debt concerns sparked a global bond selloff. The tech-heavy Nasdaq composite shed 0.8%, and the S&P 500 fell 0.7%.

Gold Just Hit a Record High. These Mining Stocks Are Glistening, Too.

Rate-cut bets, tariff uncertainty, and a central bank buying spree have driven the precious metal higher this year.

A 68% decline in shipping costs shows how retailers and manufacturers are pulling back on orders earlier than usual this year.

Trump Tariffs Are Back in Limbo. What Comes Next for the White House, Trade Partners, Companies

Courts have ruled against the legality of the president's tariff plan, raising new questions about trade deals, tariff refunds, and revenue.

As the cost of government debt spirals amid concerns over fiscal spending, the changing profile of bond investors looks set to further increase the likelihood of yield spikes going forward, according to analysts.

Russia, China Close In on Pipeline Deal, Leaving Beijing With the Upper Hand

The two countries advanced plans for the long-delayed pipeline to funnel Russian fuel to China but left core terms unresolved, a sign of Beijing's growing leverage.

A long-awaited trade agreement will be presented on Wednesday as Brussels races to secure trade deals while tensions with the U.S. mount.

Thirty-year gilt yields hit their highest level since 1998, German 30-year yields were at their highest since 2011 and French 30-year yields reached their highest since 2009.

The extra levy meant to punish New Delhi for buying cheap Russian crude isn't going as expected.

Annual inflation picked up pace a little in the eurozone last month, cementing expectations that the ECB will leave interest rates unchanged next week.

Members of OPEC+ are set to meet Sunday to discuss production policy as the market braces for a global supply glut that is expected to pressure prices.

The result comes despite weak economic growth, underpinning expectations that the ECB will leave its key interest rate unchanged next week.

A private gauge of China's manufacturing activity rose to a five-month high, though questions linger over whether the rebound can be sustained.

South Korea's headline inflation eased for the second consecutive month to a nine-month low in August, remaining below the central bank's 2% target and paving the way for more rate cuts to support the economy.
summary: Stocks fell in September amid rising bond yields and inflation concerns, leading to a global bond selloff. The Nasdaq composite dropped 0.8%, and the S&P 500 fell 0.7%. Gold has risen due to rate-cut bets, tariff uncertainty, and a central bank buying spree. A 68% decline in shipping costs indicates retailers and manufacturers are pulling back on orders earlier than usual this year. Courts have ruled against the legality of the president's tariff plan, raising questions about trade deals, tariff refunds, and revenue. A long-awaited trade agreement will be presented as Brussels attempts to secure trade deals amid tensions with the U.S. Russia, China, and Ukraine advance plans for a pipeline to transport Russian fuel to China but leave core terms unresolved.
shortSummary: Stocks began September on a down note as bond yields hit historic highs amid renewed inflation and debt concerns, while China faces trade tensions with the US.
argos_summary: U.S. stocks opened September lower as renewed inflation and debt worries spurred a global bond selloff, with the Nasdaq falling 0.8% and the S&P 500 down 0.7%. Gold hit a record high amid rate‑cut bets and tariff uncertainty, while shipping costs fell 68% as manufacturers pull back orders. Rising bond yields and a surge in government debt have heightened expectations of further yield spikes, and tariff disputes—particularly involving Trump’s plan—add to trade uncertainty. Meanwhile, Russia and China edge closer to a pipeline deal, OPEC+ prepares to address a looming supply glut, and the ECB is expected to keep rates unchanged next week.
